courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Systemic Anatomy
courses.description: This course introduces the major organ systems in the human body by delivering the knowledge of how a system is basically composed and how different components function intimately in accomplishing their roles. The organization of each system is emphasized and illustrated using models and plastinated human bodies in laboratory demonstrations.
courses.component:
Discussion
Exercise
Independent Study
Lecture
Others
Practicum
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should be able to:

Knowledge:
• describe the location, general organization, composition and function of the major organ systems in the body;
• state the importance of interrelationship between different organ systems; and
• provide clinical examples related to disorder of human structures.

Skills:
• identify the position of different organs in situ; and
• recognize the structural features of different organs and to differentiate them in situ or with the aid of plastinated specimens and models.

Attitude:
• demonstrate respectfulness towards the prosected human body.
courses.course_syllabus:
eLecture Topics
- Terminology on positions and planes of sectioning
- Lymphatic system: Body defense

Lecture Topics
- Respiratory system: Lung and breathing
- Cardiovascular system: Heart and circulation
- Musculoskeletal system: Body support and movement
- Nervous system: Brain, coordination and control
- Digestive system: Digestive organs and energy supply
- Urogenital system: Elimination of wastes and continuation of life
- Introduction to radiology

Practical Topics
- Respiratory and cardiovascular systems
- Musculoskeletal system
- Nervous system
- Digestive system
- Urogenital system
courses.feedback_evaluation: Both formal and informal measures will be used to collect students' feedback on the teaching of this course. The course coordinator will meet with the class representatives on a regular basis and also will at any time collect feedback from students through various means (face-to-face, online, or email). The Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) form will be used as a formal means of collecting students' feedback.
courses.recommended_readings: Martini, F.H., Tallitsch, R B. & Nath, J. (2018) *Human Anatomy* (9th ed.). San Francisco: Pearson Benjamin Cummings. [8th edition in CU library QS4 .M356 2015]

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Cells and Tissues
courses.description: This course introduces the microscopic anatomy of cells and tissues in the human body. Histological features of different tissues and organs are emphasized and demonstrated with the use of virtual microscopy. Topics include: histology of epithelial and glandular tissues, connective tissues and extracellular matrix, muscular tissues, nervous tissues, skin and appendages, tendons and ligaments, cartilages and bones.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:

Knowledge:
• recognize the microscopic structure of normal human tissues and organs, with emphasis on the basic tissues and musculoskeletal tissues;
• relate the histological features of cells and tissues to their functions; and
• provide clinical examples related to human structures.

Skills:
• recognize histological features of different cells and tissues with the use of microscopy.
courses.course_syllabus:
Lecture – Fundamental knowledge of the histology of human tissues will be delivered through lectures. Following 2-3 lectures, exercises (e.g. multiple-choice questions) will be provided to students as a form of continuous assessment for their self-learning.

Practical – Study of the microscopic features of cells and tissues will be assisted by self- and guided examination of histological slides with the use of virtual and conventional microscopy.

Online activities – Online exercises (e.g. multiple-choice questions) of each major topic, which aim at enhancing students’ understanding of the key concepts and providing a self-testing tool, will be set and released via Blackboard.
courses.feedback_evaluation: A number of formal and informal measures will be used to collect students’ feedback on the teaching of this course. The course coordinator will meet with the class representatives on a regular basis and will also collect feedback from students at any time through various means (face-to-face or emails). The Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) form will be used as a formal means of collecting students’ feedback.

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Basic Integrative Pathology
courses.description: This course introduces the normal and pathological microscopic structure of cells and tissues in the human body. Basic histological features of different tissues and organs will be emphasized in first half, and followed by the basic pathology of the cellular and sub-cellular changes of specific tissues. These key features will be demonstrated with the use of virtual microscopy.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:

Knowledge:
• describe the specific microscopic structure of normal human tissues and organs, with emphasis on the basic tissues and skin as a combined example;
• relate the histological features of cells and tissues to their functions;
• recognize and distinguish the difference in the microscopic structure between normal and pathological human tissues and organs, with emphasis on cellular and sub-cellular changes; and
• provide clinical examples related to human structures.

Skills:
recognize histological features of different cells and tissues with the use of virtual microscopy and real microscope.
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Introduction of to conventional microscopy and virtual microscopy
2) Introduction to histology
3) Epithelial and glandular tissues
4) Connective tissues and extracellular matrix
5) Muscular tissues
6) Nervous tissues
7) Skin and appendages
8) Tendons and ligament
9) Cartilages and bone
10) Peripheral blood cells
11) Cellular injury and subcellular adaptation
12) Cell death and infarction
13) Approach to digital pathology

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Bioethics I
courses.description:
This course provides an overview of the major areas of bioethics, including historical foundation of bioethics, the four principles, health beliefs and bias in medicine, and ethical dilemmas related to distributive justice, confidentiality, and right to know. Case discussions will be extensively used in the course, allowing students to understand and explore the cause of ethical dilemmas in clinical scenarios and the underneath social dynamics, and develop their analytical and problem-solving skills for these dilemmas.

Course assessment include: a) lecture participation, b) tutorial discussion, c) module exercise, and d) term-end essay. Students must pass all individual components in order to pass the course. Failure to meet one of the assessment components will result in a “Fail” for the whole course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:

1. describe the fundamentals of argument constructions and evaluation
2. apply normative theories in ethical analysis
3. illustrate competing interests and principles in tension;
4. discuss the relationships between humanities and bioethics, and
5. communicate ideas and arguments in a clear and concise manner
courses.course_syllabus:
Module Topic:

1. An Overview of Bioethics and Western Medicine Tradition

2. Complex Medical Decision Making and Ethical Principles

3. Respect for Autonomy: A matter of Personal Choice Only?

4. Beneficence and Non-maleficence: The Best Interest vs. Avoiding Harm

5. Justice: Resource Allocation to Public Health

6. Beliefs and Bias in Medicine

7. Confidentiality vs. Right to Know: Genetics and Disclosure
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the course. Continuous feedback will be collected via discussions with the class representatives.

courses.recommended_readings: All recommended references as listed under Blackboard.

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Perspectives of Medicine in Real Life
courses.description:
Apart from knowledge gleaned from comprehensive pre-clinical basic science learning, students are encouraged to experience the actual practice of clinical medicine. Students are required to participate in simulation teaching with clinical scenarios demonstrating the importance of basic science, visit the medical museum to witness the evolution of the healthcare system in the past decades and learn the skills to make full use of the medical library through the medical library tours.

It is mandatory for students to attend all the learning activities, including visit and workshop arrange under the course. Students who are absent from the learning activities will be deemed failing the course. Competition of the course is a pre-requisition for promoting to Year 2.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:

1. be aware of the importance of basic science in the practice of clinical medicine;
2. understand the history and evolution of the healthcare system in Hong Kong; and
3. appreciate the crucial functions of the library system in supporting medical education and research.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is composed of the following elements:
1. A Workshop on Basic Life Support
2. A Workshop on Emergency Medicine
3. A Visit to the Hong Kong Museum of Medical Sciences
4. An Orientation and Tour of the Medical Library

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Digital Health
courses.description:
Digital health is a broad overarching term encompassing digital tools, technologies and services that connect and empower people and populations to manage health and wellness. Digital health varies from relatively established areas such as communication between a patient and a doctor through telemedicine to newly emerging areas such as the use of computer science in big data and artificial intelligence to enhance the accuracy of the diagnostic processes or predicting patient outcomes. In the recent years, digital health became an inevitable part of healthcare providing personalized healthcare.
This course will introduce undergraduate students to the landscape of digital health technology and the application of digital health data. Digital devices can be helpful for individuals to monitor their health through wearable devices, mobile application monitoring and home systems. These devices can have benefits to patient care and improve health. This course will provide students with the basic architecture of digital health from digital devices and data platforms, computing and data science and artificial intelligence. Students will also acquire experience of digital innovation from user and stakeholder engagement.
Students will start with an overview of digital health and then discuss research articles on social media data for disease management, new forms of health data from wearable devices and mobile APPs, and discussion on the big data and the application of artificial intelligence. Students will be divided into different teams to prepare a pitching presentation after they attend lessons from case studies and stakeholder sharing. Feedbacks and comments will be given by a team of judgement panel in the final presentation. Finally, they will be able to describe the basic components of digital health and understand the application of digital health technology through experiential learning in a pitching presentation.
courses.component:
Discussion
Lecture
Interactive Tutorial
Web-enhanced Teaching
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:

- describe components of digital health and data management

- apply knowledge in review of digital innovations in health

- write a proposal of a digital health solution using digital health technology

- understand the need of digital health from user and stakeholder perspectives

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Bioethics II
courses.description:
Bioethics is the study of the ethical issues that arise in the practice of medicine and healthcare; human biology, biological research, environment, and emerging technologies.

This course builds on the foundational topics introduced in Year 1, and discussed contemporary issues in medicine and biomedical science. It is designed to help students develop systematic strategies and analytic frameworks for identifying and examining bioethical issues and for resolving bioethical dilemmas and problems. The teaching methods for this course are lecture and tutorial format. Course assessment include; (a) lecture participation, (b) tutorial discussion, (c) module exercise, and (d) term-end essay. Students must pass all individual components in order to pass the course. Failure to meet one of the assessment components will result in a "Fail" for the whole course.

5. communicate ideas and arguments, in a clear and concise manner

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Resilience Building in Professional and Personal Development I
courses.description:
Medical schools strive to educate knowledgeable, caring and professional physicians. The growing interest in empathy, wellness and resilience has fuelled the design and implementation of structured educational programmes worldwide to cultivate empathy, especially when there is a globally increasing trend in professional burnout among undergraduates and resident trainees. Empathy in the medical setting includes appreciating the patient's emotions and the expression of that awareness. Empathy is an essential learning objective that can be cultivated. Empathy brings about patient satisfaction, promotes adherence to medical recommendations and good clinical outcomes, and more importantly, professional satisfaction. A key component of empathy is reflective capacity. Fostering reflective capacity within medical education helps develop critical thinking skills, inform clinical reasoning, and enhance professionalism among trainees. The development of reflective capacity is conducive to effective feedback in medical education and is an essential aspect of self-regulated and lifelong learning. Failure to reflect on one's thinking processes, including a critical examination of one's assumptions, beliefs, and conclusions, was recently described as a cognitive component of "physician overconfidence," a contributing cause of diagnostic error in medicine. Reflection is not necessarily intuitive, especially in students at the initial stages of their medical careers. The over-arching aim of the course is to nurture and consolidate the key soft skills of an effective doctor and a healthy resilient personality through the development of reflective capacity and empathy.

The course is delivered in progressive stages to build reflective capacity and empathy in specific professional developmental contexts. The four building blocks, as outlined below, will be emphasized in different years. The building blocks will be progressively built and integrated over the curriculum from years 2 to 4.
1. Empathic Engagement (Year 2)
2. Doctor and Society (Year 3)
3. Doctor and Self- Reflection in Practice (Year 4)
4. Doctor and Profession (Year 4)
The four components encompass the core values of a healthy and competent doctor who can foster a therapeutic alliance with patients, appreciate and reflect the meaning of work, be a team player, and connect with the public and society.

Attendance to the empathic engagement workshop is mandatory.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course comprises three parts that utilize multimodal and multimedia means, which all aim to engage students' active participation and self-reflection.

Topics: Empathy in clinical practice

Learning Contents:

1. What is empathy? What is the difference between A.I. and a clinician who loses empathy or is defeated by empathy? (Clinical, psychological and neuroscience perspectives)
2. Virtual-reality assisted experiential learning—knowing how your patients feel

Topics: Self-practice/Self-reflection approach

- adjustment to the new learning environment and develop healthy self-care habits alongside professional development.

Learning Contents:

1. Exploring your typology as a learner and strategies for effective learning in the professional curriculum.
2. Exploring perfectionism and the common cognitive schema when striving for excellence/ survival in the professional curriculum.
3. Understanding your stress response and fostering self-compassion.
4. Introduction to mindfulness practice.

Topics: Mental Health Awareness & self-care for Doctors

Learning Contents:

1. Burnout in professional practice; Common mental health problems in young people and adaptive strategies.
2. Introduction to Mental Health First Aid.
3. Resources for fostering psychological wellness and for crisis support in our community.

Workshop and Learning activities:

The practical workshops will utilize multimodal, and multimedia means. The scope of activities includes:

* theme-based didactic lectures (pre-recorded online lectures to honor a more personalized learning pace and allow a protected personal space for deeper immersion into the topics).
* self-assessment on psychological burnout, learning and coping style.
* VR-assisted experiential learning.
* self-study on suggested references and active self-reflection on the reading materials.

courses.description: This course introduces basic principles of physiological control and drug actions of various body tissues and systems. It is taught by lectures, practicals, small group tutorials, demonstrations and workshops. The topics cover the following areas: physiology of excitable cells, muscles, cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal and renal systems, mechanisms of drug actions and pharmacokinetics, and drug actions on coagulatory pathways and peripheral nervous system and gastrointestinal system.

courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students should be able to:
1) understand the physiological control of excitable tissues in the body; describe the functions of the cardiovascular, gastrointestinal and renal systems, and how these systems are regulated;
2) know the mechanisms of drug action and pharmacokinetics; and
3) identify the use of important drugs on regulating coagulatory pathways and functions of peripheral nervous and gastrointestinal systems.

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Doctor and Patient I
courses.description:
This course describes key elements in an effective doctor-patient relationship and in effective communications with the community. The course also introduces students to the biological, social and ethical aspects of health and illness.

The course has two components.

Part I is a series of visits with a medical doctor to observe, understand and acquire insight into the patient presentation and the role of a family doctor in the community and the doctor-patient relationship.

Part II is longitudinal follow-up of a family with a new born baby in order to observe and interact with a family with a newborn to be able to understand and describe influences on child development e.g. socio-economic background of the family, health beliefs and practices, family adjustment to the newborn, social support, community support, assessment of milestones etc. This course is delivered by a series of lectures, small group tutorials, presentations, visits to family doctors in the community, and interviews with a family on wards and in the community.

courses.description: This course introduces basic principles of cellular structure, cell division and death, cellular metabolism, molecular biology and medical genetics. The course provides the scientific basis in biochemical and molecular control of various cell functions, and on recent advances in genomic and personalized medicine. Topics include: cell biology; metabolism of biomolecules; basic molecular biology knowledge and techniques; modes of inheritance; developmental, clinical and population genetics; as well as their applications in diagnosis, screening and patient care.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics covered:
1) Molecular structure and function of cells
- Membrane transport
- Cell cycle and cell death
- Stem cells and differentiation
2) Cellular metabolism
- Bioenergetics
- Carbohydrate metabolism
- Lipid metabolism
- Nitrogen metabolism
- Integration of metabolism
3) Molecular biology
- Principles of molecular biology
- Techniques in molecular biology
4) Medical genetics
- Different modes of inheritance
- Developmental, clinical and population genetics
- Genomics and precision medicine

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Clinical Skills I
courses.description: The clinical skills course is the beginning of the journey of developing one’s professional identity as a physician. Students will learn the foundations of clinical skills which include history taking, physical examination and basic skills of communication. Students will be divided into small groups and each group will be led by a clinical skills teacher. This course is an experiential course. Students are expected to come prepared to class by completing the online micro-modules and the required assessments. Attendance is mandatory for all clinical skills sessions. Students will be assessed on the skills at the end of the course via an OSCE examination.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Students will know the components of a basic medical history and know how to take a basic medical history from a patient
• Students will know how to perform a physical examination for the following systems: Vital signs, Cardiovascular, respiratory, abdomen, MSK upper and lower limbs
• Students will know how to perform an ECG and its interpretation
courses.course_syllabus:
Students should be able to perform the following skills:

History Taking:
• Know how to take a patient’s complete history, which include the following components: Patient identification, presenting (Chief) complaint(s), history of presenting complaint, past medical history, medication and allergies, social history, family history, direct questioning (system review)
• Know how to use open and closed ended questions during a patient interview
• Use basic communication skills: Establish rapport with patients, listen to patient’s concerns, pay attention to verbal and non-verbal cues and be empathic with patients.

Vital Signs:
• Know how to obtain the pulse rate of a patient
• Describe the characteristics of the pulse such as rate, quality, rhythm
• Know how to obtain the pulse rate of a patient
• Know the normal range for pulse rate
• Know how to obtain the respiratory rate of a patient
• Know how to measure the arterial blood pressure (hand aneroid sphygmomanometer and Korotkoff sound technique/auscultatory method)
• Know the normal range for blood pressure
• Know how to obtain temperature of a patient
• Awareness of different methods of measuring waist circumference
• Competence in measuring the height and weight of an adult, and measuring waist circumference using WHO method
• Knowledge of how to calculate body mass index (BMI) and interpret the result according to appropriate standards

Cardiovascular System:
• Inspection of various signs pertaining to diseases of the cardiovascular system
• Pulse rate and pulse rhythm by palpation
• Recognition of jugular venous waveforms and measurement of jugular venous pressure
• Inspection and palpation of the apex beat
• Proper use of stethoscope in auscultation of the heart
• Classic sites of cardiac auscultation
• Auscultation of the first and second heart sounds and ways to differentiate the two
• Recognition of physiological splitting of the second heart sound

ECG Practical Session:
• Know how to attach the ECG leads correctly and perform a ECG on a real
person
• Know the 12-lead ECG measurement and interpretation (cardiac vector, rhythm, waveforms)

Respiratory System:
• Know the surface markings of the trachea and lung lobes
• Examination of the chest by the IPPA (Inspection, palpation, percussion, auscultation) approach
• Inspection of various peripheral signs as pertains to diseases of the respiratory system
• Inspection of the chest wall for any abnormalities
• Palpation: chest wall tenderness, trachea, chest expansion, parasternal heave, apex beat, tactile fremitus
• Know how to use proper technique to percuss the lung fields, know normal percussion note is resonant
• Use of stethoscope for auscultation in all lung fields to listen for normal breath sounds.
• Know how to perform vocal resonance and/or whisper pectoriloquy.

Abdominal System & Rectal Examination:
• Inspection of the following: General, hands, face, eyes, mouth, neck, chest
• Inspection of the abdomen
• Perform light and deep palpation of the abdomen
• Examine the liver – palpation and percussion
• Examine the spleen – palpation and percussion
• Examine the kidneys
• Examine the aorta
• Examine for ascites using the shifting dullness technique
• Auscultate for bowel sounds, renal bruit and liver bruit
• Demonstrate an understanding of the symptoms, signs, and underlying pathophysiology of common abdominal presentations
• Know the clinical features and pathophysiology of chronic liver disease
• Inspection and palpation of perineum and anus
• Digital palpation of rectum and peri-rectal space
• Digital palpation of prostate and check for size, lobes, medial sulcus, texture, consistency, nodules, tenderness

MSK System:
• Know the components of history taking, clinical examination (look, feel, move) and basic principle of treatment
• Know the structure of reaching a diagnosis and creating a management plan for patients

Final Assessment:
• OSCE on the last day of class meeting

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Resilience Building in Professional and Personal Development II
courses.description:
Medical schools strive to educate knowledgeable, caring and professional physicians. The course is delivered in progressive stages to build reflective capacity and empathy in specific professional developmental contexts. As outlined below, the four building blocks will be emphasized in different years. The building blocks will be progressively built and integrated over the curriculum from years 2 to 4.
1. Empathic Engagement (Year 2)
2. Doctor and Society (Year 3)
3. Doctor and Self- Reflection in Practice (Year 4)
4. Doctor and Profession (Year 4)

The four components encompass the core values of a healthy and competent doctor who can foster a therapeutic alliance with patients, appreciate and reflect the meaning of work, be a team player, and connect with the public and society.

Through a narrative medicine approach, Year 3 medical students are expected to explore more about the community/society to establish a connection with the public and society as team players.
The course will cover four different themes for students to explore and reflect on more.
a. War zone/humanitarian
b. Diversity, inclusion and health inequalities
c. Disability/Impairment
d. Life and Death Studies

Attendance to the visit is mandatory.
courses.course_syllabus:
Field trip/visit to the NGO or social community and interactive lecture.

The course comprises two parts that engage students' active participation and self-reflection.
Part 1: Group work in the community
Learning Contents:
1) To explore one of the four main themes of society/community in groups.
2) Group work to visit/participate in the designated organizations to explore the selected theme

Part 2: Forum for sharing
Learning Contents:
1) to reflect what students have observed during the visit
2) to discuss their concerns about the visit

Workshop and Learning activities:
- participatory observation of the community, active participation,
- group discussion (in-class),
- self-practice/self-reflection (in-class or web-based),
- reflective writing,
- group presentation on thematic research or case studies and peer review evaluation,
- self-study on suggested references and active self-reflection on the reading materials

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Doctor and Patient III
courses.description:
The doctor and patient relationship is dynamic and essential in providing medical care. The therapeutic relationship enables the health professional and the patient to become cooperatively engaged and thereby effect beneficial change in the patient. This therapeutic relationship may be a one-off encounter or can be lifelong. The student should already have a deep understanding of the challenges from the doctor’s perspective and the range and variety of medical conditions of patient presentation.

This course is a continuation of Doctor and Patient I and II and complements the experiences gleaned from the visits that are made in the family project during the child’s second and third year of life. The course aims to give students insights into the biological, social, psychological and medical context of care in the child's second and third year of life. This course is taught by a series of lectures and small group tutorials. There are family visits and interviews. The course ends after community and family medicine, paediatrics, obstetrics and gynaecology and psychiatry rotations so that the student has a comprehensive overview of the medical, developmental and social aspects to the family and child and the role of the community in health care. Case presentations in the interdisciplinary seminar discuss salient learning points in the course.

| Interdisciplinary Seminar | Discussion of learning points and topical issues in child development and family health |

courses.description: The primary focus of this course is the anatomy of the head and neck in the human body. First part introduces the organization of the extra-cranial structures; second part focuses on the organization of the central nervous system. The course is taught through lectures, supplemented with experiential learning in dissecting laboratory and other practical sessions. Different regions of the head and neck, including the bony components and associated organ systems are examined. The detailed blood supply and cranial nerve innervation is emphasized. This is followed by the study of the organization of the brain and spinal cord, and their control of the structures of the head and neck. Lastly, the embryonic development of the head and central nervous system including sense organs such as the eye and ear is discussed. It helps to enhance students' understanding of the overall complexity of this body region. The course also contains dedicated Clinical Anatomy sections to help student understand and contextualise anatomy of the head and neck, and appreciate their relevance in clinical practice. These includes clinically-orientated lectures and e-lectures.
courses.component:
Laboratory
Lecture
Interactive Tutorial
Web-enhanced Teaching
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students should be able to:
1. describe the organization and function of various structures in the head and neck, and the central nervous system;
2. identify major structures in specific regions of the head and neck and the nervous system; and
3. describe and appreciate the principles governing development of the head and neck including the central nervous system.
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Skull and cranial cavity
2) Face, orbit, nasal and oral cavity
3) Mandible and TM joint
4) Neck
5) Pharynx and larynx

7) Blood supply of head and neck
8) Cranial nerves
9) Brain and spinal cord neuroanatomy
10) Blood supply of CNS
11) Eye and inner ear
12) Development of head
13) Development of CNS
14) Basic surgical aspects of thyroid area, ear, nose and throat
15) Anatomical aspects of brain trauma

courses.description:
In continuation with MEDU3600 Basic Pathology, this course enables medical students to appreciate further the mechanisms of laboratory medicine, with emphasis on genomics and personalized medicine.

MEDU3310 aims to illustrate the principles of diseases in an organ-system approach. The course focus on common diseases of Histopathology and Hematology. The emphasis is on the clinical context in correlation with pathology features. Apart from conventional lectures and e-lectures, this course encourages students to actively discuss common case scenarios and pathology investigations during small-group tutorials in a laboratory setting.

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Chemical Pathology
courses.description: This course is designed to teach the pathophysiological basis of diseases and associated biochemical changes. Building on this knowledge, the students learn investigation and interpretation of laboratory results in Chemical Pathology and Clinical Immunology. Students learn how disease presentations and laboratory results correlate with pathophysiology. The course places emphasis on how clinical laboratory investigations play an important role in the diagnosis and management of diseases. The course also covers modern developments in laboratory genomic medicine. Students are expected to be competent in interpretation of laboratory results after completion of the course. This course includes lectures, laboratory sessions, tutorials and case discussions.

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Clinical Microbiology
courses.description: The course aims to provide medical students with an understanding of microbiological infections relevant to human beings. Emphases are placed on commonly encountered micro-organisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and parasitic organisms, and those that are pathogenic. The diagnostic approach and case management of infectious diseases are discussed. The impact of antimicrobial resistance and the mechanisms of its spread are explored. Methods for infection prevention and control measures in the hospital are also introduced in the form of Basic Infection Control Module. N95 respirator qualitative fit-test is conducted in the module.

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Integrated Clinical Communication Skills I
courses.description:
Communication ability is a core clinical skill and essential in medical consultations, determining a diagnosis, management planning and teamwork coordination. As students, at this point in their medical education, are interacting with patients, the course runs in parallel with clinical curricula by enhancing students’ communications skills as they learn to take histories, perform examinations and other clinical tasks.

Teaching modalities combine e-learning with experiential learning, self reflection and peer review and tutor feedback.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to perform the following tasks:
1. describe different communication models and components of effective communication as well as barriers to effective communication.
2. demonstrate effective verbal, non verbal, listening and empathic skills while communicating with patients.
3. critically appraise and provide helpful feedback in regard to one's own and others' communications skills.
4. demonstrate approaches and key strategies used in consultations with a child, an adolescent and the elderly.
5. describe and demonstrate approach to cultural competence and confidentiality.
6. demonstrate skills in obtaining written consent.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Topic: General principles underpinning communications with patients
Content/fundamental concepts:
General Principles
Verbal and non verbal communication
Active listening and empathic response
Calgary Cambridge guide and Demonstration

2. Topic: The competent patient
Content/fundamental concepts:
Assessing competency: child, adolescent and old age

3. Topic: Consent
Content/fundamental concepts:
Consent of investigations and procedures
Negotiating mutual plan of action
Obtaining written consent

4. Topic: Patient confidentiality
Content/fundamental concepts:
Principles and common pitfalls
Breaching patient confidentiality

5. Topic: Cultural competence
Content/fundamental concepts:
Key concepts in cultural competence
Communication barriers
Ethnic minorities in Hong Kong

Course activities will include:
Online learning and multiple choice/ short answer exercises
Video roleplay workshop
Video review and feedback tutorial
Clinical case sharing discussion

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Radiology Pathology
courses.description: The course is integrated with Radiology Anatomy (embedded in MEDU2300 Human Structure I & MEDU3300 Human Structure II in MBChB Year 2 & 3, respectively) and Basic Clinical Radiology (embedded in MEDU4710 Senior Surgical Dressership in MBChB Year 6), using the same five modules across the curriculum. These modules comprise: 1. Thorax, 2. Abdomen/Pelvis, 3. Musculoskeletal system, 4. Neurological system/ Head & Neck and 5. Imaging Modalities (Radiography, Fluoroscopy, Computed Tomography (CT), Ultrasound (US), Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), Nuclear Medicine (NM) & Interventional Radiology). The course is taught via interactive lectures with a strong case-based teaching element, annotated images, quizzes, end-of-module revision tests. Students should comply with the 50% lecture attendance requirement to pass the radiology course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
1. demonstrate competence to investigate a patient with imaging
2. request appropriate imaging investigations
a. Understand the strengths/ weaknesses of imaging investigations /modalities.
b. Select imaging investigations thoughtfully in the context of a patient’s clinical presentation, patient safety, and health care resources.
3. use imaging investigations to guide patient management.
a. Identify normal and abnormal images.
b. Suggest a differential diagnosis for emergency & common abnormalities in the context of the patient’s clinical situation and site(s) of abnormality on imaging.
c. Diagnose some emergency & common disorders on imaging.

* Good resource with details, cases and knowledge on concepts.*
Radiology Cafe: <https://www.radiologycafe.com/medical-students/radiology-basics> *Lessons and helpful quizzes to reinforce the concepts of basic radiology. Also has a downloadable e-book (free!) if you would like to learn on the go/offline mode.*

Introduction to Radiology (DartmouthU): <https://www.dartmouth.edu/~anatomy/HAE/Radiology_Intro/rad_index.html>
* Good resource for beginners and students wishing to learn about radiology. Comes with well-defined, easy to read modules and a few quizzes to help retain the learnt concepts.*

Radiology Assistant: <https://radiologyassistant.nl/>
* A helpful, free resource for the Radiology Society of the Netherlands in proving recent updates into radiology and radiological innovations/developments. It also has a good resource on common clinical problems and imaging that would be helpful for new or learning radiologists.*

Radiology Education: <https://www.radiologyeducation.com/>
* Another e-library resource with access to lectures, textbooks, teaching material and other anatomy related materials such as atlases.*

A quick blog post on learning the very essentials of radiology in a step-by-step manner: <https://www.medicalmediareview.com/teach-yourself-radiology/>

* Contains some free resources and mention of books that could be purchased for further interest and knowledge.*

Geeky Medics (Radiology): <https://geekymedics.com/category/osce/data-interpretation/radiology/>
* Summarized, key details on interpreting and collection MRI/CT scans. A good website for medical students wanting help on a wide variety of resources/learning (radiology and a lot more).*

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Resilience Building in Professional and Personal Development III
courses.description:
Medical schools strive to educate knowledgeable, caring and professional physicians. The course is delivered in progressive stages to build reflective capacity and empathy in specific professional developmental contexts. The four building blocks as outlined below will be emphasized in different years. The building blocks will be progressively built and integrated over the curriculum from years 2 to 4.
1. Empathic Engagement (Year 2)
2. Doctor and Society (Year 3)
3. Doctor and Self- Reflection in Practice (Year 4)
4. Doctor and Profession (Year 4)
The four components encompass the core values of a healthy and competent doctor who can foster a therapeutic alliance with patients, appreciate and reflect the meaning of work, be a team player, and connect with the public and society.

After completing the course MEDU3160 in Year 3, students are expected to build the reflective capacity on mapping their external and internal resources and develop sensitivity to connect with society as knowledgeable, caring, and professional physicians. Medical students are also expected to explore self and teamwork in a clinical environment with a good sense of professionalism.

A clinical medical setting is a teamwork environment with multidisciplinary professionals, e.g., doctors, nurses, pharmacists, physiotherapists, who must work together, communicate frequently, and have a common goal to care for the patients. The World Health Organization (WHO) also recommends medical students learn the principles of teamwork in their training.

Moreover, nowadays, the work duty of a doctor is heavily loaded, physically and emotionally. The development of regular self-reflection in practice would help the students enhance resilience in managing stress. In this course, Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) will be used to help the students reflect on how their values, needs, and personality traits greatly influence the helping process and style.

Apart from MBTI, Mindfulness is recognized by the leading Medical Schools worldwide as a beneficial practice for their students and residents. Mindfulness is cultivated to promote self-care, self-awareness, and empathy with the ultimate aim of mutually improving the well–being of doctors-in-training and for the long-term patient care with good quality.

The course covers three different themes for students to explore and reflect on. It includes:
a. being an effective team player; b. understanding personality type and professional Care Style through Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI); and
c. Mindfulness and Cognitive techniques for medical students.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students can:

• have higher self-awareness and understanding of their Care Style, based on their 16 MBTI personality type preferences
• have specific recommendations on how they can flex their particular Care Style to increase patient's satisfaction
• reflect on how their personality type preferences affect the teamwork, communication and potential source of stress in a clinical setting
• involve in the discussions relating to the professional issues, practical situations, and attitudes necessary for the professionals
• reflect their clinical experiences through peer review, constructive feedback, and consultation by the medical professional
• acquire and apply basic mindfulness and cognitive techniques
courses.course_syllabus:
The course is divided into two parts which aim to engage students' active participation and self-reflection.

Part 1: Mindfulness and Cognitive techniques for medical students

Part 2: Understanding personality type and professional Care Style through MBTI
- Introduction of MBTI
- Online questionnaire assessment
- Interpretation of MBTI result, Care Style and recommendations to self-development

courses.description: This course focuses on the physiological function and pharmacological regulation of the respiratory, endocrine, reproductive and nervous systems as well as the integrated control of various body functions that involve hormonal, neural, and immunological mechanisms. The course includes lectures, practicals, case discussion, and small group tutorials. Topics include: respiratory system, endocrinology, reproductive system, nervous system function, basic immunology and drug actions in these systems.

Discussion
Laboratory
Lecture
Interactive Tutorial
Web-enhanced Teaching
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students should be able to:
1. describe the functions of respiratory, endocrine, reproductive, nervous and immune systems and how these are regulated;
2. describe the integrated control of various body systems by neural, hormonal and immune mechanisms; and
3. identify the use of important drugs in regulating functions of the airway, endocrine, reproductive, central nervous and immune systems and inflammation.
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Respiratory physiology and pharmacology
2) Endocrine physiology and pharmacology
3) Reproductive physiology and pharmacology
4) Nervous system function
5) Basic immunology, and anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive drugs
6) Drugs in pain control and anaesthesia
7) Drug action on the central nervous system
8) Drug interactions / toxicology
9) Amyloidosis and hemodynamic disturbances

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Doctor and Patient II
courses.description:
The doctor and patient relationship is essential to medical care and is a dynamic relationship. A therapeutic relationship enables the health professional and the patient to engage and effect beneficial change in the patient. This therapeutic relationship may be one encounter or lifelong. The student should already have a deep understanding of the challenges from the doctor’s perspective and the range and variety of medical conditions of patient presentation.

This course is a continuation of Doctor and Patient I and takes a deeper exploration of patient’s perspective and narrative and how this impacts the patient doctor interaction and communication strategies. The student also continues to engage with the family as the child is reaching one year old and interact and observe family dynamic, child development, health beliefs and social, medical and community support.

The course has two components:
Part I: Doctor-patient relationship in the community
This is a continuation of the clinical visits with a doctor. During these visits, the attention is now drawn to the patient’s perspective and narrative in looking and listening closely to the words, tones, gestures and actions used in the patient’s experience of illness, the communication and the interaction and exchange between the doctor and the patient. Meanwhile, issues relating to caring for those in decline and dying are discussed.

Part II: Child and family development in the community
This is the continuation of the family follow up project in which the students observe, interact and gain insight into the biological, social, psychological and medical context of care in the child's first year of life.

This course is taught by a series of lectures and small group tutorials. There are clinical visits to family doctors and visits and interviews with a family.

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Clinical Anatomy and Clinical Skills
courses.description: This course is a 3-week bridging course taught at the end of the year 3, i.e., the final year of preclinical education in the MBChB programme. It is aimed to help student to revise anatomy of all body regions and appreciate their relevance in basic skills in clinical examinations of the human body. It is an intensive course taught by basic and clinical lectures, e-lectures, interactive radiology sessions and small group clinical skill practical involving actual patients.
courses.component:
Lecture
Practicum
Interactive Tutorial
Web-enhanced Teaching
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Thorax and abdomen: This session is taught in the first week. It covers a review on anatomy of thorax and abdomen, radiological examinations of these regions, diseases associated with the heart, lung and pleural cavity, abdomen and Pelvis, and inguinal hernia. Clinical skills related to examination of these regions will be taught in the practical.
2) Limbs: This session is taught in the second week. It includes normal anatomy of the upper and lower limbs, radiological examinations, and clinical problems associated with the shoulder, upper limb, hip and thigh, and knee, leg and foot. Clinical examinations of structures in the limbs will be covered in the practical.
3) Head and neck, and the spine: This session is taught in the third week, covering topics in normal structure of the skull, brain, face and neck, and vertebral column. Radiological examinations and clinical relevance of these structures are covered. Clinical examinations of cranial nerves, neck and thyroid, and neural controls of limbs and trunk will be taught in the practical.

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: WE HEAL - the learning of patient pathways to health systems
courses.description:
The course "WE HEAL - the learning of patient pathways to health systems" illustrates key concepts in the design of health systems by following the journey of a patient in the health system. Jointly organized by the Faculty of Medicine with the CUHK Medical Centre (CUHKMC), the course (MEDU3580) is the first stage of the series of "WE HEAL" courses introduced to Year 3 medical students.

Health systems are highly complex and dynamic. To deliver quality and safe care to patients, doctors need to work with a large number of stakeholders from different disciplines and professionals. Two workshops - Health System Challenges and Interprofessional Collaborative Practice – will be offered to prepare medical students for their more intense clinical exposure in clinical years. The concepts of patient-first approach, team-based care, compassionate and holistic care, evidence-based medicine practice, and ethical care will be covered in the workshops.

Teaching modalities combine lecture, workshop, e-learning with experiential learning.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to have understanding and basic concepts on the following topics.

1. To develop insights on experience of patients in their healthcare journeys.
2. To understand health system dynamics and how hospitals function in the delivery of patient care.
3. To understand the concept of interprofessional collaborative practice.
4. To understand the concept of design thinking in a healthcare context.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics:

1. Health system challenges (a 4-hour workshop)
* Concept of health system in Hong Kong and worldwide
* Concept of quality of care
* Concept of patient journey
* Concept of design thinking in patient pathway
2. Interprofessional collaborative practice (a 4-hour workshop)
* Concept of team care
* Concept of interprofessional education
* Concept of holistic care along patient journey​

Course activities will include:

* Online learning: 2 hours
* Workshops: 8 hours

courses.description:

Week 1 consists of general pathologic principles by Anatomical Pathology. Week 2 includes of immunology subjects by Chemical Pathology and Forensic Pathology particulars. Week 3 will be on Basic Infection Control by Microbiology.

This intensive summer course includes lectures, e-lectures, laboratories and small-group tutorials.

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Bioethics III
courses.description:
The course builds on the foundational knowledge by covering advanced topics and contemporary issues, including moral theories, brain death, end-of-life issues, physician-assisted suicide, ethics of cosmetics surgeries, and conscientious objection.

This course includes a series of lectures given by clinicians, nurses, public health specialists, and bioethicists. Students will be introduced to the substantial debates in the field and try their hand at taking part in the discussion. Students will benefit from this course such that they will be more skilled in making sound arguments.

Group Presentation assessments require you to research a particular topic in a small group and then prepare and deliver an oral presentation on the topic. In the presentation, students are expected to demonstrate an adequate understanding of the topic and highlight details that are ethically and morally challenging. They should also give constructive feedback to peers during the Q&A session.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:

1. recognise and cogently discuss significant questions in the humanities, arts, and the natural and social science
2. identify critical trends, events, and episodes that have influenced the development of bioethics
3. analyse the social, political, cultural, and scientific factors that have shaped the development of bioethics;
4. present clear, concise and carefully reasoned arguments in writing and presentation
courses.course_syllabus:
Module Topic:

1. From Moral Theories to Ethical Analysis
2. End-of-life: Withholding/Withdrawing Life-sustaining Treatment
3. End-of-life: Brain Death & Physician-assisted Suicide
4. Between Curative Medicine and Human Enhancement
5. Conscientious Objection
6. Student Presentation I, II & III

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Bioethics IV: Law and Medicine
courses.description: The course builds on the foundation of Years 1-3 studies in bioethics to consider physician obligation expressed in law, regulations, professional codes and widely held norms of medical ethics. Areas considered include the doctor-patient relationship, patient capacity, consent, confidentiality, medical error and negligence, forensic pathology and related medical-legal issues and end of life care. Students would learn about the legal system, the difference between civil law and criminal law, law and procedure, the court system and the law making process. Students should know their important role in society as physicians and as law-abiding citizens, in upholding justice and being a role model for others, in protecting the weak and vulnerable and in the prevention of crime.
courses.component:
Classwork
Debate
Discussion
Independent Study
Lecture
Interactive Tutorial
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:

* understand the Hong Kong legal framework governing selected ethically complex topics in clinical practice and policy
* recognize professional standards for selected ethical topics in clinical practice and policy and the generally accepted normative standards and requirements
* understand their responsibilities in meeting the challenges of medical error and medical negligence
* understand the basic principles and methodology of forensic medicine
* understand the basic principles relating to Advanced Directives (AD) and know the difference between AD and Advance Care Planning (ACP)
* understand the importance of making rational decisions and the consequences of their behavioural choices
* grasp the basic requirements and standards applicable to medical registration and professional governance
* participate in a moot hearing on disciplinary inquiry of medical error and negligence
courses.course_syllabus:
This course will consist of five to eight modules of case-based study of legal, professional and normative standards governing:
1. The doctor patient relationship and issues relating to patient capacity, consent, confidentiality
2. Medical error and medical negligence
3. Laws, regulations and norms relating to the beginning of life
4. Laws, regulations and norms relating to the end of life care
5. Forensic pathology and related medical-legal issues

General legal topics will include:
6. Introduction to the legal system and public health laws
7. Important legislation related to medical practice, .e.g. anti-discrimination legislation, protection of privacy legislation, offences against the persons ordinance, theft ordinance, public health and municipal services ordinance, medical registration ordinance, etc. (Specialist areas will be covered in the clinical years.)

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Clinical Skills II
courses.description:
This course is a continuation of Clinical Skills I course. The clinical skills course is the beginning of the journey of developing one’s professional identity as a physician. Students will learn the foundations of clinical skills which include history taking, physical examination and basic skills of communication. Students will be divided into small groups and each group will be led by a clinical skills teacher. This course is an experiential course. Students are expected to come prepared to class by completing the online micro-modules and the required assessments.
Attendance is mandatory for all clinical skills sessions. Students will be assessed on the skills at the end of the course via an OSCE examination.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Students will know the components of a basic medical history and know how to take a basic medical history from a patient
• Students will know how to perform a physical examination for the following systems: Cranial nerves, limbs and cerebellum, ear and eye, breast, hernia, neck and thyroid
courses.course_syllabus:
Students should be able to perform the following skills:

Cranial Nerves:
• Use the appropriate stimulus to test cranial nerve (CN) I.
• Test the following CN II functions: visual acuity, visual fields by confrontation, and pupillary light reflex.
• Perform the swinging flashlight test and recognize the clinical significance of a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).
• Examine extraocular movements (smooth pursuit), accommodation (convergence, pupillary constriction), and for the presence of nystagmus (by pausing at end-gaze).
• Examine pain, temperature and light touch sensation within CN V distribution, and examine the muscles of mastication.
• Test the muscles of facial expression and recognize the clinical signs of a CN VII lesion, including the difference between an upper motor neuron (UMN) and a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion affecting CN VII.
• Assess CN VIII via air and bone conduction tests to detect gross hearing loss and determine the type (i.e., conductive vs. sensorineural).
• Elicit the gag reflex and examine for palatal elevation, as well as describe the clinical signs of an unilateral lesion affecting CN IX and X.
• Test CN XI by assessing muscle bulk and power in sternocleidomastoid and trapezius.
• Examine the tongue with respect to movements, power, and the presence of atrophy and fasciculations

Limbs and Cerebellum:
• Conduct a thorough motor examination of the upper and lower extremities:
o Inspect for involuntary movements, fasciculations, atrophy
o Assess for tone
o Assess for power in the major muscle groups
o Elicit the biceps, triceps, brachioradialis, knee and ankle reflexes
o Elicit ankle clonus and plantar response (Babinski sign)
• Conduct a sensory examination of the upper and lower extremities: Light touch, pain, vibration sense, position sense, Romberg’s test
• Conduct a gait assessment: Look for abnormal gait (e.g. antalgic gait, spastic diplegic gait, scissoring gait, ataxic gait, high- stepping gait, shuffling gait)
• Conduct an examination to assess for coordination (cerebellum)

Ear & Eye:
• Know how to examine the outer and middle ear
• Be able to hold and use an otoscope correctly
• Know how to perform a hearing test
• Know how to perform voice hearing test and turning fork tests

• Know the principle of vision test and how to check for visual acuity
• Know how to hold and use the ophthalmoscope correctly
• Know how to perform direct fundoscopy

Breast Examination:
• Inspect the breast for any asymmetry, obvious masses, skin changes, scars
• Inspect the nipples for any deviation, retraction, eczematous changes, discharge
• Palpation of the breast – examines all quadrants, retro areolar region and axillary tail
• Describes any abnormalities such as mass
• Examines the axilla for lymph node groups

Hernia Examination:
• Know the different types of hernias: Reducible, incarcerated, strangulated hernias
• Know the difference between an inguinal and a femoral hernia
• Differentiate between a direct inguinal hernia and an indirect inguinal hernia
• Exam hernia by inspection and palpation
• Know the anatomical landmarks – pubic tubercle, ASIS, deep inguinal ring, femoral artery
• Check for presence of cough impulse, or mass with or without a cough impulse
• Check for reducibility of any mass and use of control test
• Examine for the testis and spermatic cord
• Perform transillumination and ability to get above any mass in the scrotum

Neck and Thyroid Examination:
• Know how to examine for lymph nodes in the head and neck by inspection and palpation
• Know the different group of lymph nodes in the head and neck
• Be able to describe an abnormal lymph node
• Know how to examine the thyroid gland by inspection, palpation and auscultation
• Know the clinical signs for hyper/hypothyroidism

Final Assessment
• One OSCE station on the last day of class meeting

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Clinical Pathology and Clinical Skills
courses.description:
In the advanced clinical skills portion of this course, students will review the physical exam of the cardiovascular, respiratory, abdominal, neurological and MSK systems. Students have learned the normal physical exams of the above systems during years 2 and 3. In this portion of the course, we will focus more on the abnormal signs so that students can correlate these findings to real life situations. Students will be divided into small groups and each group will be led by a clinical skills teacher. In the Forensic Pathology portion, students are expected to learn the changes of the human body after death, and be familiar with forensic investigations of death, including examination of wounds and injuries, forensic aspects of asphyxia and injuries, sexual offences, abortion, and child abuse. In the Microbiology portion of this course, students will be taught the essential knowledge and basic principles of infection control, including standard and transmission-based precautions, use of common personal protection equipment, precautions of sharps injury and blood and body fluid exposure and disinfection and sterilization. Students will be equipped with essential infection control knowledge necessary for clinical attachments.

This course is an experiential course. Students are expected to come prepared to class by reviewing the materials learned previously. Attendance is mandatory for all clinical skills sessions.

courses.course_syllabus:
* *Advanced Clinical Skills**
Students should be able to perform the following skills:

Cardiovascular System (1.5 hours):
• Inspection of various signs pertaining to diseases of the cardiovascular system
• Pulse rate and pulse rhythm by palpation
• Recognition of jugular venous waveforms and measurement of jugular venous pressure
• Inspection and palpation of the apex beat
• Proper use of stethoscope in auscultation of the heart
• Classic sites of cardiac auscultation
• Auscultation of the first and second heart sounds and ways to differentiate the two
• Recognition of physiological splitting of the second heart sound
• Know the findings and characteristics of murmurs

Respiratory System (1.5 hours):
• Know the surface markings of the trachea and lung lobes
• Examination of the chest by the IPPA (Inspection, palpation, percussion, auscultation) approach
• Inspection of various peripheral signs as pertains to diseases of the respiratory system
• Inspection of the chest wall for any abnormalities
• Palpation: chest wall tenderness, trachea, chest expansion, parasternal heave, apex beat, tactile fremitus
• Know how to use proper technique to percuss the lung fields, know normal percussion note is resonant
• Use of stethoscope for auscultation in all lung fields to listen for normal breath sounds.
• Know how to perform vocal resonance and/or whisper pectoriloquy.
• Know what crackles, wheezes, rubs sound like
• Know how to interpret abnormal findings to come up with potential diagnoses

Abdominal System & rectal examination (1.5 hours):
• Inspection of the following: General, hands, face, eyes, mouth, neck, chest
• Inspection of the abdomen
• Perform light and deep palpation of the abdomen
• Examine the liver – palpation and percussion
• Examine the spleen – palpation and percussion
• Examine the kidneys
• Examine the aorta
• Examine for ascites using the shifting dullness technique
• Auscultate for bowel sounds, renal bruit and liver bruit
• Demonstrate an understanding of the symptoms, signs, and underlying pathophysiology of common abdominal presentations
• Know the clinical features and pathophysiology of chronic liver disease
• Know the signs of an acute abdomen
• Inspection and palpation of perineum and anus
• Digital palpation of rectum and peri-rectal space
• Digital palpation of prostate and check for size, lobes, medial sulcus, texture, consistency, nodules, tenderness

Cranial Nerves: (1.5 hours)
• Use the appropriate stimulus to test cranial nerve (CN) I.
• Test the following CN II functions: visual acuity, visual fields by confrontation, and pupillary light reflex.
• Perform the swinging flashlight test and recognize the clinical significance of a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).
• Examine extraocular movements (smooth pursuit), accommodation (convergence, pupillary constriction), and for the presence of nystagmus (by pausing at end-gaze).
• Examine pain, temperature and light touch sensation within CN V distribution, and examine the muscles of mastication.
• Test the muscles of facial expression and recognize the clinical signs of a CN VII lesion, including the difference between an upper motor neuron (UMN) and a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion affecting CN VII.
• Assess CN VIII via air and bone conduction tests to detect gross hearing loss and determine the type (i.e., conductive vs. sensorineural).
• Elicit the gag reflex and examine for palatal elevation, as well as describe the clinical signs of an unilateral lesion affecting CN IX and X.
• Test CN XI by assessing muscle bulk and power in sternocleidomastoid and trapezius.
• Examine the tongue with respect to movements, power, and the presence of atrophy and fasciculations
• Know the common abnormal findings of the cranial nerve examination

Limbs and cerebellum: (1.5 hours)
• Conduct a thorough motor examination of the upper and lower extremities:
o Inspect for involuntary movements, fasciculations, atrophy
o Assess for tone
o Assess for power in the major muscle groups
o Elicit the biceps, triceps, brachioradialis, knee and ankle reflexes
o Elicit ankle clonus and plantar response (Babinski sign)
• Conduct a sensory examination of the upper and lower extremities: Light touch, pain, vibration sense, position sense, Romberg’s test
• Conduct a gait assessment: Look for abnormal gait (e.g. antalgic gait, spastic diplegic gait, scissoring gait, ataxic gait, high- stepping gait, shuffling gait)
• Conduct an examination to assess for coordination (cerebellum)
• Know the commons signs of upper and lower motor neuron lesions

MSK Upper extremities (1.5. hours)
• Know how to examine the shoulder and elbow
• Know the common pathologies relating to the shoulder and elbow

MSK Lower extremities (1.5 hours)
• Know how to examine the hip and knee
• Know the common pathologies relating to the hip and knee

* *Forensic Pathology**
• Changes After Death and Forensic Investigation of Death (2 hours)
• Forensic Aspects of Asphyxia and Injuries (1 hours)
• Forensic Aspects of Sexual Offences, Abortion and Child Abuse (1 hours)

* *Microbiology**
• Principles of infection control; Standard precautions and transmission-based isolation precautions; Hand hygiene
• Use of common personal protective equipment including disposable N95 particulate respirators
• Precautions on sharps injury and blood and body fluid exposure including post exposure management
• Disinfection and sterilization
• Hospital hygiene
• Contemporary issues in infection control
• Basic Infection Control Module practical (2 hours practical)

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Community and Family Medicine Module
courses.description:
This course provides 9 weeks of integrated teaching in Community and Family Medicine.

In Community Medicine, three major areas are covered: Epidemiology and Biostatistics, Public Health Medicine, and Occupation and Environmental Medicine. The principles and practice of public health, the application of epidemiological study methods, and the prevention and control of communicable, non-communicable and occupational diseases are introduced to students. In addition to lectures, clinical attachments, interactive/practical sessions, field visits, group work, and presentations in seminars and tutorials are utilised to facilitate learning.

The clinical clerkship in Family Medicine teaches practical family medicine skills and equips students with the understanding and ability to diagnose and manage common medical conditions that present in primary care settings. Throughout the clerkship, students are taught skills in making differential diagnoses of presenting symptoms, prioritisation of multiple medical conditions and investigations and management of common medical problems in the community. Students also gain exposure to the basic principles and practice of family medicine, i.e., providing primary, comprehensive, holistic and continuing person centred care. The clinical clerkship consists of online teaching and case based seminars, clinical team based learning workshops, clinical attachments to private family medicine doctors, Hospital Authority clinics and community health centres and health care providers for vulnerable populations. To facilitate learning, role playing in workshops and clinical enhanced skills training are provided. Facilities utilised for this clinical teaching include the University Family Medicine Clinics, and Family Medicine clinics run by Hospital Authority and private practitioners, both in public and private settings throughout Hong Kong.

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Obstetrics and Gynaecology Module
courses.description:
This 9-week module includes 4 clinical rotations that are based mainly at the Prince of Wales Hospital: (1) antenatal clinic and ward; (2) gynaecology clinic and ward; (3) labour ward; and (4) O&G services in affiliated hospitals. Core materials are covered in online lectures, tutorials and bedside teaching.

During the antenatal attachment, students gain understanding of normal pregnancy, the development and growth of the unborn child, and acquire skill in performing obstetrics examination.

In the labour ward attachment, students participate in the care and delivery of normal pregnancies, as well as observe operative deliveries. They learn common problems and emergencies in childbirth and the postpartum period.

In the gynaecology rotation, students learn common gynaecological conditions and neoplasm of the female reproductive tract. They also acquire skill in gynaecological examination. Communication skills in taking history and conducting discussions on issues regarding sexuality and reproduction are emphasized.

Students have the opportunity to rotate to the O&G unit in one of the following affiliated hospitals for attachment: Princess Margaret Hospital, Tuen Mun Hospital, United Christian Hospital, Queen Elizabeth Hospital and Kwong Wah Hospital. Students are also assigned an attachment at the Family Planning Association during the module.

courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the rotations, students are expected to be able to manage and counsel patients on common obstetric and gynaecological problems in a primary care setting.
1. Understand how to obtain obstetric & gynaecological history from patients with common O&G problems and communicate appropriately with female patients including sensitive issues in the medical history
2. Learn how to perform obstetric, speculum and bimanual examination in female patients
3. Learn how to order appropriate investigations for common obstetrics and gynaecological conditions, derive the correct diagnosis and formulate a management plan
4. Identify pregnancy risks and provide appropriate counselling
5. Recognise obstetric and gynaecological emergencies and formulate management plan
6. Diagnose and discuss the management of common malignancies and pre-malignant conditions in female patients
7. Become familiar with various obstetrics and gynaecological procedures
8. Discuss the management of common women’s health issues and counsel patient on screening and primary disease prevention
9. Become aware of major ethical and medical-legal issues related to O&G practice
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Communication, human factors and ethics, clinical skills
2. Normal pregnancy and labour, antenatal care, nutrition in pregnancy & lactation.
3. Complex pregnancy: Maternal medicine, intrapartum care & obstetric emergencies, high-risk pregnancy, infections in pregnancy
4. Multiple pregnancy
5. Early pregnancy complications
6. Reproductive Medicine: gynae-endocrinology, infertility, contraception and sexual health, post-reproductive health
7. Gynaecology: common gynaecological investigations, benign gynaecology and gynaeoncology
8. Gynaecological Surgery: preoperative care, surgical treatment, post operative care.

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Skills Module for Medicine Year 6
courses.description:
Skills Module for Medicine Year 6 is embedded in the medical and surgical modules.

Lifelong learning skills provide a “medical professionalism” component. Medical professionalism is primarily concerned with the attributes and behaviours of physicians in the practice of Medicine. The teaching of medical professionalism builds on introductory lectures provided in prior years and informal "role modeling" that occurs during the clinical curriculum. The module is designed to expand the students' cognitive base for professionalism, and to provide opportunities for internalizing related values and behaviours by collaborating in small group problem solving sessions. The workshops require analysis and development of moral solutions for simulated ethical dilemmas. Feedback provided by small groups to their whole class enables reflection and informed discussions.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Practice lifelong learning skills.
2. Demonstrate professional collaboration.
3. Use ethical and moral principles to resolve ethical dilemmas within simulated contexts.

Lifelong learning skills
Evidence-based practice embedded within clinical bedside and tutorial teaching.
Professional Conduct Integrated Teaching Session: Lecture 1h, problem based learning tutorial 2h followed by class presentations 1.5h = 4.5h

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Paediatrics Module
courses.description: During this 9-week clinical module in paediatrics, students participate in a range of learning activities both in the hospital and in the community. Hospital-based experiences include the wards and outpatient clinics of the Prince of Wales Hospital as well as other regional hospitals. Students are exposed to primary care paediatrics in community-based centres, including the Maternal and Child Health Centres, Child Assessment Centres, Hong Chi Pinehill School and primary care private paediatric clinics. Pre-recorded online lectures and case-based teaching are combined with face-to-face bedside and tutorial teaching on clinical methods, reasoning and management. As part of the mentorship programme, students attend interactive teaching on bioethics and communication skills. Students will also undergo simulation-based medical education to enhance their skills in paediatric patient assessment, management of paediatric emergencies, team work in crisis management, and communication skills. Group-based activities allow small-group and individual feedback opportunities from both the mentors/instructors as well as peer feedback.

Lecture
Others
Practicum
Seminar
Interactive Tutorial
Visit
Web-enhanced Teaching
courses.course_syllabus:
On the first day of the module students will be given an introduction to the Paediatric Clinical Method to emphasize differences in approach that might exist between adults and children and between older children and younger children.
Students will be allocated to one of eight groups (consisting of 8-9 students per group) that will rotate through the Prince of Wales Hospital and two of the four outside hospitals (United Christian Hospital, Kwong Wah Hospital, Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital and Princess Margaret Hospital).

Pre-recorded online lectures, case-based teaching and assessments are available on the Blackboard for the students. Students will visit a Child Assessment Centre and also learn about the Student Health Service.
On Tuesdays, students in groups will visit a number of regional hospitals (Hong Kong Children’s Hospital, Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital, Tseung Kwan O Hospital, Queen Elizabeth Hospital, Tuen Mun Hospital, Caritas Medical Centre) and outside institutions ( Maternal & Child Health Clinic, Child Assessment Centre, Heep Hong Early Education and Training Centre, Watchdog Early Education Centre).
On Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays students will undertake ward work which will involve clerking patients, participating in tutorials and bedside teaching sessions and attending outpatient clinics.
Students will also participate in case studies and role play as interactive teaching on communication skills and give presentations on important bioethical topics.

Students will also undergo simulation-based medical education to enhance their skills in paediatric patient assessment, management of paediatric emergency, team work in crisis management, communication skills.
