courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Clinical Ethics I
courses.description:
This course introduces ethical dilemma arising from some special circumstances in the clinical practice of each discipline.

In the Family Medicine module, students will learn about issues in common clinical encounter, including presentation of serious conditions at early stage, disclosure of information, breaking the bad news, patient autonomy, confidentiality, conflict of interests, duty to third parties, and dealing with clinical errors. Through small group teachings, students will be able to discuss challenges and forumulate possible solutions.

Main objective: To teach medical students the potential medico-legal pitfalls and the ethical dilemmas in daily family practice as family physicians will be asked to undertake various tasks not within the boundary of conventional healthcare setting.

Specific objective: To teach Year 5 medical students of The Chinese University of Hong Kong the potential medico-legal pitfalls in daily family practice and the ethical dilemmas in daily practice. It will build on the teaching in year 4.

Students must read the note and refresh what they have learnt from Bioethics course especially in Year 4 before coming to class for meaningful interactive discussion.

In the Obstetrics and Gynaecology module, students will learn about ethical issues through the interactive student forum and seminar, such as termination of pregnancy, reproductive autonomy in the face to emerging technologies, as well as obstetricians' role in the decision-making between pregnant women and the potential human — fetus.

In the Paediatrics module, students will learn about bioethical considerations that paediatricians face while treating children for health conditions. For children, unlike for adult patients, healthcare decisions are often made by someone other than the person to be treated, i.e. by the parents/primary carers. Issues of patient confidentiality, consent for treatment, and child protection require the treating doctor to be aware of the specific needs and desires of the child, and to be able to respect and adequately address situations when the child's and parents' views and needs diverge.

In the Psychiatry module, students will learn about common and unique bioethical considerations that psychiatry faces while treating patients with mental health conditions, such as patient confidentiality, consent for treatment in psychiatric illness, and capacity determination.

In addition, students are required to attend the annual Lanson Lecture hosted by the CUHK Centre for Bioethics.
courses.learning_outcomes:
* To develop moral sensitively to identify the ethical problems that arise in day-to-day clinical practice
* To determine the right course of action when unethical practices or behaviours are observed in clinical practice

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Psychiatry Module
courses.description:
The goal for this 9-week course in psychiatry is to enable students to:
1. understand the relationship between the psychological, biological and social determinants of psychiatric disorders; 2. acquire basic practical knowledge in diagnosing and managing psychiatric disorders of major public health concerns; 3. become acquainted with the organization of psychiatric services in Hong Kong.
A variety of teaching methods are employed including Team base learning workshops, seminars, small-group tutorials, attendance of ward rounds, case conferences and outpatient clinics and visits to several psychiatric facilities (hospitals and community facilities).
courses.component:
Lecture
Others
Practicum
Interactive Tutorial
Visit
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Take a psychiatric history and perform a thorough mental-status examination, cognitive and neuropsychiatric assessment.
2. Understand the principles of psychiatric diagnosis and current classification of mental disorders.
3. Appreciate mind-body connections, i.e., being aware of the interactions between psychiatric and medical diseases and the impact that mental disorders have on personal, social and occupational functioning.
4. Understand the basic pharmacology and therapeutic use of psychotropic drugs, as well the basic principles of psychological interventions.
5. Become familiar with the principles of psychiatric rehabilitation and recovery within the medical system and NGOs in the community.
6. Be aware of major ethical issues related to psychiatric and medical practice, such as mental capacity, treatment consent, and mental health ordinance.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Affective disorders.
2. Anxiety and Depressive disorders in the community stress-related disorders also including phobic states, obsessive/compulsive disorder
3. Schizophrenic and paranoid disorders.
4. Neurocognitive disorders Common psychiatric disorders in the elderly.
5. Neuropsychiatric conditions.
6. Alcohol and drug abuse.
7. Psychiatric disorders in relation to medical and surgical diseases.
8. Major psychiatric disorders in childhood such as emotional and conduct disorders.
9. Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorders and Autistic Spectrum Disorders.
10. Disorders of sleep and circadian rhythms.
11. Personality disorders, including the special relevance of psychopathic personality disorder in forensic medicine, and alcohol and drug abuse.

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Integrated Clinical Communication Skills II
courses.description:
Communication skills are core clinical skills that are essential in the medical consultation for effective diagnosis, management planning and teamwork coordination. The aims of this course are to
a) manage consultation dynamics and development of specialty
communication skills in family medicine, obstetrics and gynaecology,
paediatrics and psychiatry, b) demonstrate health communication with public (Cantonese).
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students should be able to:

1. describe and demonstrate approach in consultation of sensitive issues, motivational interviewing, negotiating patient agendas and complex consultations which may encompass: breaking bad news, giving diagnosis,
motivation interviewing, triadic consultations etc,
2. reflect and critically appraise their own and others’ consultation skills as a lifelong learner
3. understand the needs of the public in terms of information and communication
4. demonstrate a short informative health communication on a health topic.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Topic: Advanced communications skills
Content/ key concepts:
Cambridge Calgary guide (Explaining and planning)
Managing consultations
Motivational interviewing

2. Topic: Collecting sensitive information
Content/ key concepts: Communication skills in taking a sexual history and psychiatry history

3. Topic: Discipline Specific Skills in: Community and Family Medicine, Obstetrics and Gynaecology, Paediatrics and Psychiatry modules
Content/ key concepts:
Enhancing communication skills (including negotiating agendas,beraking bad news, managing consultations) within the context of discipline specific consultations.

Course activities will include:
Online learning
Communication and consultation skills workshops (in respective modules)
Video assignment and reflection
Soundbite demonstration
Tutor and peer feedback

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Clinical Ethics II
courses.description:
The MED6 curriculum emphasises clinical teaching through hospital rotations in medicine, surgery, and other sub-specialised disciplines, including anaesthesia, intensive care, clinical oncology, ear, nose and throat, emergency medicine, cardiothoracic surgery, neurosurgery, and orthopaedics and trauma. Alongside the essential medical knowledge required for everyday care, students must also learn to navigate the complex and multifaceted landscape of healthcare relationships among all stakeholders and the ethical challenges that arise within it.

Parallel to clinical teaching, the MED6 Clinical Ethics II course will enable students to apply the moral reasoning principles in healthcare delivery. The curricular design leverages clinical experiences to promote ethical decision-making and the resolution of dilemmas. In doing so, students will develop tangible critical thinking skills to prevent and resolve doctor-patient conflicts, which is a crucial step in the transition to becoming medical professionals. Students are expected to identify the ethical issues, resolve the dilemmas through an ethical reasoning process, and implement their decisions through communication with patients or their surrogates.
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Understand ethical theories and apply moral reasoning principles to recognise, present, and resolve ethical dilemmas in clinical settings.
* Utilise reasoning abilities to identify the root causes of ethical dilemmas.
* Address conflicts through critical thinking to evaluate relevant clinical ethics issues and communicate with patients and families.
* Appreciate the multifaceted nature of the doctor-patient relationship and demonstrate empathy when discussing ethically challenging issues with patients and families.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Introductory lecture (1 hour) (Whole class)
* Ethics Round (1.5 hours) (Whole class)
* Multi-media engagement (1.5 hours) (Whole class)
* Moral reasoning module/video assignment (3 hours) (Small group teaching)
* Workshop on ethics and law (2 hours) (Small group teaching)
* Concluding lecture (1 hour) (Whole class)

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Clinical Elective
courses.description:
Under the guidance of, and with the approval of, the Coordinator of Clinical Electives, each student will design and undertake a self-directed clinical elective in Hong Kong or overseas, tailored to their career aspirations. Students should focus on immersive, experiential learning across diverse healthcare settings with activities that help further develop their clinical competencies.

Key components:
Personalised learning plan – students design and implement a structured plan outlining clinical competencies, immersive activities, and self-directed objectives aligned with their professional development.
Critical reflection – students reflect on variations in healthcare settings, ethical challenges, and/or innovative clinical practices experienced during the elective.
Effective communication – students communicate experiences and insights gained during the elective through a multimedia portfolio (e.g., reflective summaries, visual documentation).
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To develop and carry out a personalised learning plan for the clinical elective, which includes components such as clinical competencies, immersive activities and/or self-directed objectives aligned with career aspirations.
2. To reflect on observations and experiences during the clinical elective in terms of variations in healthcare systems, ethical practices and/or innovative approaches.
3. To communicate experiences and insights effectively.

Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the module.
Continuous feedback will be collected via discussions with the class representatives.

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Integrated Clinical Communication Skills III
courses.description: Communication skills are core clinical skills essential in both inpatient and outpatient encounters for effective diagnosis, management planning, and interdisciplinary coordination. This course, the final part of the series of clinical communication courses spanning the preclinical and clinical years, focuses on the practical application of these skills in a complex clinical environment. The teaching activities are interwoven within medical and surgical rotations to enhance the integration of these core skills into mainstream clinical teaching. Teaching modalities combine e-learning, experiential learning, self and peer reviews, and tutor feedback.

courses.title: Combined Clinical Examination
courses.description:
The Combined Clinical Examination consists of:
1. End of year Combined Clinical Examination which is cooperatively administered by the Departments of Obstetrics & Gynaecology, Paediatrics and Psychiatry, and the School of Public Health and Primary Care. The examination consists of a written paper and a structured clinical examination and complements the discipline based module examinations.
2. Family follow up project

courses.learning_outcomes:
End of year Combined Clinical Examination

The examination assesses the students’

1. competence in the clinical method (i.e., taking a history, reaching a working
diagnosis, understanding principles of management and associated social
and psychological consequences;
2. understanding and appreciation of the interface and interdependence
between these disciplines;
3. understanding how a clinical problem affects the whole person and
complement the discipline orientated part of the examination;
4. appreciation of how patients might present in a primary care setting.

To assess the students’ abilities, a written paper and a structured clinical examination in applying the clinical method, i.e., taking a history, reaching a working diagnosis, and understanding the principles of management and their social and psychological consequences.

Family follow up project

Update report and topic study group assignment from the family follow up project.

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Senior Medical Clerkship
courses.description:
The Senior Medical Clerkship consists of two ten-week modules, referred to as Medicine A and Medicine B. Medicine A consists of attachments to the medical wards in Princess Margaret Hospital, North District Hospital, Shatin Hospital, Our Lady of Maryknoll Hospital, and Prince of Wales Hospital as well as Clinical Skills Lab and one week of Assistant Intern (AI) Programme shadowing Medical Officers at the Prince of Wales Hospital. Students are attached to each of the above hospitals/unit in rotation. Medicine B involves attachments to medical wards under the supervision of the Department of Medicine and Therapeutics, Department of Clinical Oncology, and Accident and Emergency Medicine Academic Unit as well as a one week of AI Programme shadowing Interns in the Prince of Wales Hospital. Students are attached to each of the above Departments in rotation in order to learn by daily clinical contact with patients in the respective wards. Students are encouraged to clerk patients and present during subspecialty rounds, and to follow patients’ progress during their hospital stay. Subspecialty teaching sessions are also held every Wednesday throughout the two modules. Students are attached to subspecialty activities and outpatient clinics during their respective rotations. Bedside teaching of clinical skills is arranged in small groups twice weekly. All students in these medical rotations are expected to attend medical grand rounds every Wednesday.

A total of two-week AI Programme shadowing with one-week AI Programme shadowing Medical Officers is integrated into Medicine A module while a one-week AI Programme shadowing Interns is integrated into Medicine B module. Students shadow the frontline doctors to learn and experience daily clinical work with both inpatients and outpatients. Requiring active participation in clinical activities under close supervision by the frontline doctors, the programme is designed to help students develop core competencies as medical professionals. The AI Programme aims to nurture self-initiative, sense of responsibility, stress coping strategies, communication skills and social responsibility through experiential learning in actual clinical settings.

Small group tutorials during both clerkships as well as during AI are provided in order to further develop students' communication skills within clinical and professional settings. This includes presenting in medical rounds, writing patients' scripts and referrals, having communications with lay public concerning medical matters, handling complaints and bad news, organizing and presenting literature or decision making in clinical conferences. These skills are assessed formally in the end-of-module examinations and are also an obligatory component of final year graduating examinations. Multidisciplinary integrative sessions are maintained throughout this course.

courses.subject: MEDU
courses.title: Senior Surgical Dressership
courses.description:
The Senior Surgical Dressership consists of two ten-week modules involving small group attachments under the supervision of the Department of Surgery, Department of Orthopaedics and Traumatology, Department of Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences, Department of Anaesthesia and Intensive Care, Department of Imaging and Interventional Radiology and Department of Otorhinolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery.

The attachments include professional rounds, outpatient clinics and the operating rooms in the Prince of Wales Hospital, North District Hospital, Yan Chai Hospital, Queen Elizabeth Hospital, and Hong Kong Eye Hospital. Students work with qualified professionals in order to gain hands-on clinical experience (as in an apprenticeship). Students receive small group bedside teaching on each ward. Clinical management of patients in various specialties and essential clinical skills for junior doctors are the main foci in this training.

Small group tutorials are held during both the Dressership as well as during the Assistant Internship period for purposes of developing communication skills in clinical and professional settings. This includes students presenting in medical rounds, writing patients' scripts and referrals, communicating with lay public concerning medical matters, handling complaints and bad news, organizing and presenting literature or decision making in clinical conferences. These skills are assessed formally at end-of-module examinations and are also an obligatory component in final year graduating examinations. Assessments include continuous assessments throughout their attachment, Long case assessment (Objective Structured Long Examination Record), written exams, an OSCE and a Clinical Examination that includes history taking, physical examination, interpretation of physical signs and investigations as well as management of patients with common surgical conditions.
